intro: Petrorhagia suffruticosa, commonly known as the sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region and parts of Central Asia. It is a low-growing, shrubby perennial that typically reaches heights of 10–30 centimeters. The plant produces clusters of small, pale yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are gray-green, hairy, and adapted to reduce water loss in arid environments. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats.
